   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 10198**] is a 51 year old female with HCV cirrhosis who was
   transferred from an OSH after presenting with cough, HA,
   encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days with a hospital course complicated
   by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.
   - Ventilate with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings.
   - Titrate to FiO2 and PEEP by ABG
   - f/u Sputum, BAL, blood and urine cultures for source of sepsis
   - Vanco and pip/tazo for empiric HAP pneumonia given unclear history of
   antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that the patient
   is a hospital SW.  In addition, given suspicion for post-influenza
   pneumonia, S.aureus is also a concern. Will also treat with
   ciprofloxacin for atypical and GNR coverage.
   - Tamiflu at 75 mg po bid dosing given renal failure
   - f/u Influenza swab
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis.
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - diagnostic paracentesis per liver recs
   - Tamiflu and antimicrobials as above.
   - Monitor UOP, lactate for signs of end organ damage. Vasopressors and
   IVF for volume rescucitation as necessary.
   - Will also do a cosyntropin stimulation test to rule out hepatoadrenal
   syndrome. (results pending this morning)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential includes pre-renal azotemia, ATN,
   or HRS.  Given hypotension, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion.
   FeNa 0.2 and PFI 0.3 so likely prerenal.  No EOS on smear so not likely
   AIN
   - Continue to follow UOP and Cr.
   - Volume rescucitation as above.
   .
   # Liver disease: Patient with MELD 29 HCV cirrhosis with acute
   decompensation, likely in setting of sepsis and ARDS.
   - Consult hepatology
   - Patient is not currently on lactulose and [**Last Name (LF) 2911**], [**First Name3 (LF) 124**] hold off
   for now pending hepatology evaluation.
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to hypovolemia in setting of SIRS.
   - Trend serum sodium
   - Volume resuscitation as above
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy: Patient with thrombocytopenia,
   anemia, and coagulopathy.  Chronic thrombocytopenia likely secondary to
   portal hypertension and splenic sequestration, although current
   platelet count worse that baseline. Coagulopathy and anemia could also
   be secondary to worsening HCV cirrhosis, although DIC is also a
   potential etiology.  Anemia could also be secondary to bleeding.
   - Trend platelets, transfuse for plt<10 or <50 if signs of bleeding.
   - DIC and hemolysis labs.
   - Guaiac stools, OGT suctioning to assess for blood
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Likely due to infectious process.
   - Trend WBC
   .
   FEN: NPO, replete as necessary, IVF as above.
   PPx: SCDs, PPI
   Access: RIJ CVL, PIV (18, 20g)
   Code: Full (confirmed)
   Communication: [**Known lastname **],[**Name (NI) **] (husband) [**Telephone/Fax (5) 10199**]
   Disposition: ICU level of care
Summary:
Summary:
- The patient is a 51-year-old female with HCV cirrhosis who presented with cough, HA, encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days.
- She was transferred from an OSH after experiencing hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia.
- The patient meets criteria for ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF.
- She is being ventilated with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings and titrated to FiO2 and PEEP by ABG.
- Blood and urine cultures, as well as sputum and BAL cultures, are pending for source of sepsis.
- She is receiving empiric HAP pneumonia coverage with Vanco and pip/tazo, as well as ciprofloxacin for atypical and GNR coverage.
- Tamiflu is being administered at 75 mg po bid dosing due to renal failure.
- An influenza swab is also being followed up.
- The patient's severe sepsis includes hypoxia and hypotension, with potential infectious sources such as bacterial pneumonia or influenza.
- A diagnostic paracentesis has been recommended to rule out SBP.
- Vasopressors and IVF are being used for volume resuscitation as necessary.
- A cosyntropin stimulation test will be done to rule out hepatoadrenal syndrome.
- Acute renal failure is suspected, with a likely pre-renal azotemia

Summary:
The patient is a 51-year-old female with HCV cirrhosis who was transferred from an outside hospital (OSH) after presenting with respiratory distress. She was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. The patient also had a central IJ placed for pressors and an arterial line for ABG draw and BP monitoring. A bronchoscopy revealed mucus in her bronchi, and she was pan cultured and started on antibiotics for empiric coverage of PNA and abdominal causes. The patient received fluid boluses and was started on pressor support.

The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies. Her last doses of antibiotics were Vancomycin at 05:54 PM on 12/28, Ciprofloxacin at 10:00 PM on 12/28, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) at 06:00 AM on 12/29.

The patient is currently sedated and intubated. Her vital signs include a temperature of 36.0 C (96.8 F), heart rate of 109 bpm, blood pressure of 97/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. She has a sinus tachycardia rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 18.8 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL, elevated creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL, and decreased platelet count of 49 K/uL. Her liver enzymes are also elevated, with ALT at 82 U/L and AST at 224 U/L. Other labs such as PT/PTT/INR, electrolytes, and albumin are within normal range.

The patient's imaging shows diffuse patchy opacities bilaterally on a chest X-ray, which may represent pulmonary edema or ARDS. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) from the left lower lobe showed no microorganisms.

The patient's assessment includes hypoxic respiratory failure, severe sepsis, acute renal failure, liver disease, hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy, and leukocytosis. The plan involves ventilating the patient with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings, titrating FiO2 and PEEP by ABG, and following up on sputum, BAL, blood, and urine cultures for the source of sepsis. The patient is also being treated with antibiotics for empiric HAP pneumonia, as well as ciprofloxacin for atypical and GNR coverage. Additionally, Tamiflu is being administered for influenza.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, progression of sepsis leading to septic shock, further deterioration of renal function, exacerbation of liver disease, development of bleeding due to thrombocyt

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 10198**] is a 51 year old female with HCV cirrhosis who was
   transferred from an OSH after presenting with cough, HA,
   encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days with a hospital course complicated
   by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.
   - Ventilate with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings.
   - Titrate to FiO2 and PEEP by ABG
   - f/u Sputum, BAL, blood and urine cultures for source of sepsis
   - Vanco and pip/tazo for empiric HAP pneumonia given unclear history of
   antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that the patient
   is a hospital SW.  In addition, given suspicion for post-influenza
   pneumonia, S.aureus is also a concern. Will also treat with
   ciprofloxacin for atypical and GNR coverage.
   - Tamiflu at 75 mg po bid dosing given renal failure
   - f/u Influenza swab
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis.
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - abdominal u/s to look for fluid to possible tap for SBP diagnosis
   - diagnostic paracentesis per liver recs if indicated by abdominal u/s
   - fluid resuscitation with NS and albumin 50g
   - Tamiflu and antimicrobials as above.
   - Monitor UOP, lactate for signs of end organ damage. Vasopressors and
   IVF for volume rescucitation as necessary.
   - Will also do a cosyntropin stimulation test to rule out hepatoadrenal
   syndrome. (results pending this morning)
   - levophed and vasopressin drips as needed.  Vasopressin to try and
   wean levophed drip.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential includes pre-renal azotemia, ATN,
   or HRS.  Given hypotension, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion.
   FeNa 0.2 and PFI 0.3 so likely prerenal.  No EOS on smear so not likely
   AIN
   - Continue to follow UOP and Cr.   Our goal of UOP is 50cc/hour
   - Volume rescucitation w/ 3 amps bicab in D5W  d/t acidosis
   .
   # Liver disease: Patient with MELD 29 HCV cirrhosis with acute
   decompensation, likely in setting of sepsis and ARDS.
   - f/u Hepatology recs
   - Start lactulose
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to hypovolemia in setting of SIRS.
   - Trend serum sodium
   - Volume resuscitation as above
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy: Patient with thrombocytopenia,
   anemia, and coagulopathy.  Chronic thrombocytopenia likely secondary to
   portal hypertension and splenic sequestration, although current
   platelet count worse that baseline. Coagulopathy and anemia could also
   be secondary to worsening HCV cirrhosis, although DIC is also a
   potential etiology.  Anemia could also be secondary to bleeding.
   - Trend platelets, transfuse for plt<10 or <50 if signs of bleeding.
   - DIC and hemolysis labs.
   - Guaiac stools, OGT suctioning to assess for blood
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Likely due to infectious process.
   - Trend WBC
   .
   FEN: tube feeds and nutrition consult, replete as necessary, IVF as
   above.
   PPx: SCDs, PPI
   Access: RIJ CVL, PIV (18, 20g)

Summary:
The patient is a 51-year-old female with a history of HCV cirrhosis, who presented with cough, HA, encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days. She was treated with ceftriaxone at OSH and experienced hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. On arrival to MICU, she was tachypneic with an SaO2 of 88% on 15L face mask increased to 95% NRB. 

The patient was intubated and a central IJ was placed for pressors, an ART line for ABG draw and BP monitoring, and a bronchoscopy which revealed mucus in her bronchi. She was pan cultured and started on Vanc, Zosyn, and Cipro for empiric coverage of PNA and abdominal causes. She received fluid boluses and was started on pressor. 

The patient has been stable since then. She has multiple comorbidities including severe sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, liver disease, hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy, and leukocytosis. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, progression of sepsis, further deterioration of renal function, exacerbation of liver disease, development of electrolyte imbalances, and complications related to thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy.

The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications. The chief complaints include respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hypotension, cirrhosis, pneumonia, and acidosis. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has a history of encephalopathy.

Based on the provided information, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient has a history of acute respiratory failure with CXR suggestive of ARDS. This condition involves severe inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs, leading to impaired oxygenation.

2. Renal Failure: The patient's urine output is less than 30 cc/hr, indicating acute renal failure. Renal failure can occur due to various reasons, including decreased blood flow to the kidneys, infection, or injury.

3. Sepsis: The patient is diagnosed with severe sepsis, which is a systemic response to infection. Sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction and can be life-threatening if not promptly treated.

4. Acidosis: The patient is experiencing metabolic acidosis, which is characterized by an imbalance in the body's pH level due to excess acids. Acidosis can be a result of inadequate oxygenation, kidney dysfunction, or infection.

5. Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level of 10.0 g/dL, indicating anemia. Anemia can contribute to fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.

Summary:
The patient is a 51-year-old female with a history of HCV cirrhosis who presented with cough, HA, encephalopathy, and fever. She has been experiencing hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. The patient's hospital course has been complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure, severe sepsis, acute renal failure, liver disease, hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy, leukocytosis, and hyperglycemia. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient currently meets criteria for ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Ventilation with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings has been initiated. The goal is to wean down PEEP first and then decrease FiO2 as tolerated.
2. Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension are concerning for an infectious process. Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or influenza. Empirical antibiotic coverage has been started.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and there is a concern for pre-renal azotemia, ATN, or HRS. Fluid management and close monitoring of urine output and creatinine levels are important.
4. Liver disease: The patient has a history of HCV cirrhosis with acute decompensation. Rising liver function tests and low albumin levels indicate worsening

She has been transferred from an OSH and is currently in the ICU. Her condition is concerning for an influenza type picture or a post-influenza bacterial pneumonia. She meets criteria for ARDS and severe sepsis. The patient has acute renal failure, likely secondary to hypotension and inadequate perfusion. She also has hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, coagulopathy, leukocytosis, and hyperglycemia.

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's symptoms of cough, fever, and sore throat, along with the presence of bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray, suggest a possible infectious etiology such as influenza or bacterial pneumonia. If not appropriately managed, this can lead to further deterioration in respiratory function and potentially result in ARDS.

2. Sepsis: The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings indicate severe sepsis. If not promptly and adequately treated, sepsis can progress to septic shock, which can be life-threatening.

3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has acute renal failure, which may be secondary to hypotension and inadequate renal perfusion. This can

3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is compromised, as indicated by elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output. This increases the risk of further renal damage and potential kidney failure.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 10198**] is a 51 year old female with HCV cirrhosis who was
   transferred from an OSH after presenting with cough, HA,
   encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days with a hospital course complicated
   by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. Her overall
   picture is concerning for an influenza type picture, although she has a
   negative DFA, or a bacterial PNA, or both.
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.
   - Ventilate with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings.
   - Will try to wean her PEEP today
   - If she doesn
t improve tomorrow, consider doing esophageal balloon
   tomorrow to evaluate a good PEEP for her
   - f/u Sputum, BAL, blood and urine cultures for source of sepsis
   - Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage empirically, given unclear
   history of antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that
   the patient is a hospital SW.
   - Influenza is negative, stopped Tamiflu
   - Keep her in reverse Trendelberg
   - Albuterol/Ipratropium prn
   - consider diuresis this afternoon.
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis.
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - consider tapping her ascites seen on abd u/s
   - will get bladder pressure today to evaluate for intra-abdominal
   pressure
   - if she doesn't improve would consider further imaging (CT torso) but
   not thought to be high yield
   - ABx as above
   - watch UOP and lactate through the day --> UOP meeting goal of 50cc/hr
   this morning
   - Has started Hydrocortisone for poor cortisol stimulation test
   - Continue pressors and try to wean Levo first, then Vasopressin,
   however if she continues to be hypoNa then would stop ADH first
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential includes pre-renal azotemia, ATN,
   or HRS.  Given hypotension, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion.
   FeNa 0.2 and PFI 0.3 so likely prerenal.  No EOS on smear so not likely
   AIN
   - Continue to follow UOP and Cr.  Our goal of UOP is 50cc/hour
   - If volume resuscitation needed today would go with NS boluses
   .
   # Liver disease: Patient with MELD 29 HCV cirrhosis with acute
   decompensation, likely in setting of sepsis and ARDS. LFT's are rising
   this am, albumin is low
   - f/u Hepatology recs
   - Start lactulose
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to hypovolemia in setting of SIRS, and then
   got 2L D5W with bicarb
   - Repeat Na this pm
   - Volume resuscitation as above
   - If Na continues to be low, would wean the Vasopressin before the
   Levophed
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy: Patient with thrombocytopenia,
   anemia, and coagulopathy.  Chronic thrombocytopenia likely secondary to
   portal hypertension and splenic sequestration, although current
   platelet count worse that baseline. Coagulopathy and anemia could also
   be secondary to worsening HCV cirrhosis. DIC was considered, but labs
   are not consistent with this etiology.   Anemia could also be secondary
   to bleeding. MCV is also elevated. Three point Hct drop over yesterday,
   and INR rising through yesterday.
   - Hct this pm
   - folate and B12 for elevated MCV
   - Trend platelets, transfuse for plt<10 or <50 if signs of bleeding.
   - DIC and hemolysis labs --> add on fractionation of Tbili to this am's
   labs
   - Guaiac stools, OGT suctioning to assess for blood
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: Likely due to 2L of D5W she received today. Ordered
   for qid fingersticks, but no insulin.
   - Rept fingerstick and would consider starting insulin if persistently
   elevated.
   .
   FEN: stop tube feeds, replete as necessary, IVF as above.
   PPx: SCDs, Pepcid
   Access: RIJ CVL, PIV (18, 20g), arterial line

- Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage empirically, given unclear history of antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that the patient is a hospital SW.

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 10198**] is a 51 year old female with HCV cirrhosis who was
   transferred from an OSH after presenting with cough, HA,
   encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days with a hospital course complicated
   by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. Her overall
   picture is concerning for an influenza type picture, although she has a
   negative DFA, or a bacterial PNA, or both.
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.
   - Ventilate with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings.
   - Will try to wean her PEEP today
   - If she doesn
t improve tomorrow, consider doing esophageal balloon
   tomorrow to evaluate a good PEEP for her
   - f/u Sputum, BAL, blood and urine cultures for source of sepsis
   - Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage empirically, given unclear
   history of antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that
   the patient is a hospital SW.
   - Influenza is negative, stopped Tamiflu
   - Keep her in reverse Trendelberg
   - Albuterol/Ipratropium prn
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis.
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - consider tapping her ascites seen on abd u/s
   - will get bladder pressure today to evaluate for intra-abdominal
   pressure
   - if she doesn't improve would consider further imaging (CT torso) but
   not thought to be high yield
   - ABx as above
   - watch UOP and lactate through the day --> UOP meeting goal of 50cc/hr
   this morning
   - Has started Hydrocortisone for poor cortisol stimulation test
   - Continue pressors and try to wean Levo first, then Vasopressin,
   however if she continues to be hypoNa then would stop ADH first
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential includes pre-renal azotemia, ATN,
   or HRS.  Given hypotension, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion.
   FeNa 0.2 and PFI 0.3 so likely prerenal.  No EOS on smear so not likely
   AIN
   - Continue to follow UOP and Cr.  Our goal of UOP is 50cc/hour
   - If volume resuscitation needed today would go with NS boluses
   .
   # Liver disease: Patient with MELD 29 HCV cirrhosis with acute
   decompensation, likely in setting of sepsis and ARDS. LFT's are rising
   this am, albumin is low
   - f/u Hepatology recs
   - Start lactulose
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to hypovolemia in setting of SIRS, and then
   got 2L D5W with bicarb
   - Repeat Na this pm
   - Volume resuscitation as above
   - If Na continues to be low, would wean the Vasopressin before the
   Levophed
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy: Patient with thrombocytopenia,
   anemia, and coagulopathy.  Chronic thrombocytopenia likely secondary to
   portal hypertension and splenic sequestration, although current
   platelet count worse that baseline. Coagulopathy and anemia could also
   be secondary to worsening HCV cirrhosis. DIC was considered, but labs
   are not consistent with this etiology.   Anemia could also be secondary
   to bleeding. MCV is also elevated. Three point Hct drop over yesterday,
   and INR rising through yesterday.
   - Hct this pm
   - folate and B12 for elevated MCV
   - Trend platelets, transfuse for plt<10 or <50 if signs of bleeding.
   - DIC and hemolysis labs --> add on fractionation of Tbili to this am's
   labs
   - Guaiac stools, OGT suctioning to assess for blood
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: Likely due to 2L of D5W she received today. Ordered
   for qid fingersticks, but no insulin.
   - Rept fingerstick and would consider starting insulin if persistently
   elevated.
   .
   FEN: tube feeds, replete as necessary, IVF as above.
   PPx: SCDs, Pepcid

The patient also has signs of severe sepsis, likely secondary to an infectious process. This includes hypoxia, hypotension, leukocytosis, tachypnea, and potential sources of infection such as bacterial pneumonia or influenza. Alternative infectious sources include spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) or urosepsis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 51-year-old woman with a history of HCV cirrhosis, PNA, ARDS, and no definitive bug identified but suspected influenza or influenza with superinfection. She has been receiving various medications including antibiotics, vasopressin, fentanyl, midazolam, norepinephrine, and others. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 110/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for recent events mentioned. Her physical examination reveals distended abdomen, right and left lower extremity edema, warm skin, and unresponsiveness with no movement or follow commands. Laboratory results show abnormal values including low sodium, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient's current assessment includes alteration in nutrition, hypotension, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), renal failure, and severe sepsis. The plan includes continuing antibiotic therapy, starting reglan for abdominal distension, trying to wean off pressors, addressing hyponatremia, and improving renal function. The patient is critically ill and will remain in the ICU.

Summary:
The patient is a 51-year-old female with HCV cirrhosis who presented with cough, HA, encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days. She has been transferred from an OSH and her hospital course has been complicated by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. The patient's overall picture is concerning for either influenza or a post-influenza bacterial pneumonia. She currently meets criteria for ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other potential etiologies include IIPs such as AEP and AIP, although less likely in the setting of viral prodrome.

The patient is intubated and sedated, with coarse bilateral airway noises. She has pinpoint pupils that are reactive to light. Her abdomen is soft with hypoactive bowel sounds. Extremities show +2 edema, which are warm and well perfused.

Laboratory findings indicate leukocytosis, elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST), elevated bilirubin levels (direct and total), low albumin, prolonged PT/PTT/INR, and elevated D-dimer. Other lab results include elevated white blood cell count, low platelet count, low hemoglobin, and elevated lactate levels.

The patient has several medical complications including hypoxic respiratory failure, severe sepsis, acute renal failure, liver disease, hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy,

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 10198**] is a 51 year old female with HCV cirrhosis who was
   transferred from an OSH after presenting with cough, HA,
   encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days with a hospital course complicated
   by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. Her overall
   picture is concerning for an influenza type picture, although she has a
   negative DFA, or a bacterial PNA, or both.
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.
   - Ventilate with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings.
   - PEEP weaned to 8 and now back to 10 because of low O2.  Will attempt
   to wean FiO2 to 40% and PEEP to 8 again.
   - If she doesn
t improve tomorrow, consider doing esophageal balloon
   tomorrow to evaluate a good PEEP for her
   - f/u Sputum, BAL, blood and urine cultures for source of sepsis
   - Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage empirically, given unclear
   history of antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that
   the patient is a hospital SW.
   - Keep her in reverse Trendelberg
   - Albuterol/Ipratropium prn
   - consider diuresis this afternoon.
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis.
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - consider tapping her ascites seen on abd u/s
   - if she doesn't improve would consider further imaging (CT torso) but
   not thought to be high yield
   - ABx as above
   - watch UOP and lactate through the day --> UOP meeting goal of 50cc/hr
   this morning
   - Has started Hydrocortisone for poor cortisol stimulation test
   - Continue pressors and try to wean Levo first, then Vasopressin,
   however if she continues to be hypoNa then would stop ADH first
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential includes pre-renal azotemia, ATN,
   or HRS.  Given hypotension, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion.
   FeNa 0.2 and PFI 0.3 so likely prerenal.  No EOS on smear so not likely
   AIN
   - Continue to follow UOP and Cr.  Our goal of UOP is 50cc/hour
   - If volume resuscitation needed today would go with NS boluses
   .
   # Liver disease: Patient with MELD 29 HCV cirrhosis with acute
   decompensation, likely in setting of sepsis and ARDS. LFT's are rising
   this am, albumin is low
   - f/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to hypovolemia in setting of SIRS, and then
   got 2L D5W with bicarb
   - Repeat Na this pm
   - Volume resuscitation as above
   - If Na continues to be low, would wean the Vasopressin before the
   Levophed
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia/anemia/coagulopathy: Patient with thrombocytopenia,
   anemia, and coagulopathy.  Chronic thrombocytopenia likely secondary to
   portal hypertension and splenic sequestration, although current
   platelet count worse that baseline. Coagulopathy and anemia could also
   be secondary to worsening HCV cirrhosis. DIC was considered, but labs
   are not consistent with this etiology.   Anemia could also be secondary
   to bleeding. MCV is also elevated. Three point Hct drop over yesterday,
   and INR rising through yesterday.
   - folate and B12 for elevated MCV when tolerating tube feeds
   - Trend blood counts
   - DIC and hemolysis labs --> add on fractionation of Tbili to this am's
   labs
   - Guaiac stools, OGT suctioning to assess for blood
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: Likely due to 2L of D5W she received today. Ordered
   for qid fingersticks, but no insulin.
   - Rept fingerstick and would consider starting insulin if persistently
   elevated.
   .
   FEN: stopped tube feeds, replete as necessary, IVF as above.
   PPx: SCDs, Pepcid
   Access: RIJ CVL, PIV (18, 20g), arterial line
   Code: Full (confirmed)
   Communication: [**Known lastname **],[**Name (NI) **] (husband) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10199**]
   Disposition: ICU level of care
Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient has several medical conditions that need to be considered:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient meets the criteria for ARDS, which include a PaO2/FiO2 ratio less than 100, bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, and no evidence of congestive heart failure. The patient is already being ventilated with volume-cycled assist-control (AC) mode at ARDSnet settings.

2. Severe Sepsis: The patient's hypoxia and hypotension are concerning for an infectious process, with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis. Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or influenza. Empirical antibiotic coverage has been initiated.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has evidence of pre-renal azotemia, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion. Monitoring urine output (UOP) and serum creatinine levels is ongoing. If necessary, volume resuscitation with normal saline (NS) boluses will be administered.

4. Liver Disease: The patient has chronic HCV cirrhosis with acute decompensation, likely triggered by sepsis and ARDS. Liver function tests (LFTs) are rising, and albumin levels are low. Hepatology recommendations and lactulose therapy will be followed.

5. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia likely due to hypovolemia in the setting of SIRS. Sodium

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 51-year-old female with HCV cirrhosis who was transferred to the ICU after presenting with cough, HA, encephalopathy, and fever. The patient's symptoms are concerning for either influenza or a post-influenza bacterial pneumonia. She currently meets criteria for ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less likely in the setting of a viral prodrome.

The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. She has been ventilated with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings. PEEP has been weaned to 8 and then back to 10 due to low O2. FiO2 is being attempted to be weaned to 40% and PEEP to 8 again. If the patient does not improve tomorrow, an esophageal balloon may be evaluated to assess a good PEEP for her.

Sputum, BAL, blood, and urine cultures have been ordered for the source of sepsis. The patient is receiving Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage empirically. She is also being kept in reverse Trendelenburg position, and albuterol/ipratropium is being administered as needed. Diuresis has been held for the afternoon.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 51-year-old woman with HCV cirrhosis who was admitted with pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), likely due to influenza. The patient has shown improvement and has been weaned off pressors. She has a history of hypotension, septic shock, acute renal failure, and severe sepsis. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 71 bpm, blood pressure of 106/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's physical examination reveals right lower extremity edema, left lower extremity edema, and distended abdomen. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin level, elevated potassium level, and low albumin level. The patient is currently receiving various medications including antibiotics, vasopressin, midazolam, fentanyl, famotidine, and nutritional support through NovaSource Renal. The patient's renal function has improved, and she is producing good urine. The patient is stable with controlled ascites and septic shock, but remains critically ill.

   Ms. [**Known lastname 10198**] is a 51 year old female with HCV cirrhosis who was
   transferred from an OSH after presenting with cough, HA,
   encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days with a hospital course complicated
   by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. Her overall
   picture is concerning for an influenza type picture, although she has a
   negative DFA, or a bacterial PNA, or both.
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.
   - Ventilate with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings.
   - PEEP weaned to 8 and now back to 10 because of low O2.  Will attempt
   to wean FiO2 to 40% and PEEP to 8 again.
   - If she doesn
t improve tomorrow, consider doing esophageal balloon
   tomorrow to evaluate a good PEEP for her
   - f/u Sputum, BAL, blood and urine cultures for source of sepsis
   - Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage empirically, given unclear
   history of antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that
   the patient is a hospital SW.
   - Keep her in reverse Trendelberg
   - Albuterol/Ipratropium prn
   - hold on diuresis this afternoon.
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis.
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - consider tapping her ascites seen on abd u/s
   - if she doesn't improve would consider further imaging (CT torso) but
   not thought to be high yield
   - ABx as above
   - watch UOP and lactate through the day --> UOP meeting goal of 50cc/hr
   this morning
   - Has started Hydrocortisone for poor cortisol stimulation test
   - Continue pressors and try to wean Levo first, then Vasopressin,
   however if she continues to be hypoNa then would stop ADH first
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential includes pre-renal azotemia, ATN,
   or HRS.  Given hypotension, likely secondary to inadequate perfusion.
   FeNa 0.2 and PFI 0.3 so likely prerenal.  No EOS on smear so not likely
   AIN
   - Continue to follow UOP and Cr.  Our goal of UOP is 50cc/hour
   - If volume resuscitation needed today would go with NS boluses
   .
   # Liver disease: Patient with MELD 29 HCV cirrhosis with acute
   decompensation, likely in setting of sepsis and ARDS. LFT's are rising
   this am, albumin is low
   - f/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to hypovolemia in setting of SIRS, and then
   got 2L D5W with bicarb
   - Repeat Na this pm
   - Volume resuscitation as above
   - If Na continues to be low, would wean the Vasopressin before the
   Levophed

   portal hypertension and splenic sequestration, although current

Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure of 117/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. She is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 330 mL, respiratory rate set at 30 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%. The ABG results show a pH of 7.49, PaCO2 of 40 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 186, and HCO3- of 31 mEq/L. 

The patient has a history of cirrhosis, alteration in nutrition, hyponatremia, ARDS, acute renal failure, and severe sepsis. She is also experiencing respiratory failure, fluid overload, and musculoskeletal pain. Her renal function is improving with good urine output. 

The plan includes weaning off PEEP and FiO2, giving Lasix to address fluid overload, holding medications that may contribute to her condition, starting lactulose for encephalopathy, and continuing to monitor her coagulopathy.

She was transferred to the ICU and her hospital course has been complicated by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. The overall picture is concerning for an influenza-like illness, although she has tested negative for DFA, bacterial PNA, or both.

The patient currently meets the criteria for ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other potential etiologies include IIPs such as AEP and AIP, although less likely in the setting of a viral prodrome. The patient is being ventilated with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings, PEEP weaned to 8 and now back to 10 due to low O2 saturation. If there is no improvement, consideration will be given to performing an esophageal balloon tomorrow to evaluate a good PEEP for her.

Sputum, BAL, blood, and urine cultures have been ordered to identify the source of sepsis. Antibiotics have been started empirically with Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for HAP PNA coverage. The patient is in reverse Trendelenburg position, and albuterol/ipratropium are given as needed. Diuretics have been held, with the goal of achieving negative fluid balance. Corrective

   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly

   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less
   likely in setting of viral prodrome.

   to wean PEEP to 8 again.

   history of antibiotics and recent admissions, as well as the fact that
   the patient is a hospital SW.

   higher SpO2 than we are seeing on the monitor
   - monitor mental status, as now off sedation, and need more alert for
   extubation
   .

   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or

 wean

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female with HCV cirrhosis who was transferred from another hospital. She presented with cough, HA, encephalopathy, and fever for 3 days. The hospital course was complicated by hypotension requiring peripheral dopamine and hypoxia. The overall picture is concerning for an influenza-type picture, although she has a negative DFA or bacterial PNA.

The patient currently meets criteria for ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other potential etiologies include IIPs such as AEP and AIP, although less likely in the setting of viral prodrome. The patient is being ventilated with volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings, and PEEP is being weaned to 8 and now back to 10 due to low O2. The plan is to attempt to wean PEEP to 8 again, and if the patient does not improve, an esophageal balloon will be considered tomorrow to evaluate a good PEEP for her.

Her platelet count is within normal range, but her white blood cell count is slightly elevated. Other lab values indicate abnormalities in electrolyte levels and liver function tests.

The patient's physical examination reveals jaundice, edema in both lower extremities, clear breath sounds, and altered mental status with poor responsiveness.

The patient's medical complications include cirrhosis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure, hypotension, and sepsis. The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory function, further deterioration of renal function, development of hepatic encephalopathy, and worsening coagulopathy.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current conditions include:
1. Infection: The patient has severe sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's response to an infection causes injury to its own tissues and organs. The presence of fever, cough, and positive yeast growth in BAL cultures indicate a possible fungal infection.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure has progressed to ARDS, a serious lung condition that can lead to respiratory failure. It is characterized by rapid onset of widespread inflammation in the lungs.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has acute renal failure, which is a sudden episode of kidney dysfunction or failure. It can be caused by various factors, including dehydration, sepsis, and low blood flow to the kidneys.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's HCV cirrhosis has led to acute decompensation, resulting in liver failure. This condition can cause

Summary:
The patient is a 51-year-old woman with a history of cirrhosis, PNA/ARDS, who became hypertensive, tachycardic, and agitated overnight. She was given boluses of versed/fentanyl, but attempts at spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) were unsuccessful due to her remaining hypertensive and tachycardic. 

The patient has a fever of 101.9F and received antibiotics including vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn). She is currently on propofol infusion, fentanyl, midazolam (Versed), famotidine (Pepcid), lactulose, rifaximin, chlorhexidine, hydrocortisone, and SSI. 

Her vital signs show a maximum temperature of 39.1C (102.4F) and current temperature of 37.7C (99.9F), heart rate (HR) of 97 bpm (94-132 bpm), blood pressure (BP) ranging from 138/72 mmHg to 179/94 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) of 15 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation (SpO2) at 100%, and sinus rhythm (SR). 

Fluid balance shows a total input of 2,581 mL and output of 2,930 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 349 mL. The patient is receiving respiratory support through an endotracheal tube with CPAP/PSV mode, set tidal volume (Vt) of 330 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%, respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 64, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 14 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 20 cmH2O, and compliance of 27.5 cmH2O/mL. 

The patient's blood work reveals a white blood cell count (WBC) of 16.4 thousand/mm3, hemoglobin (Hct) of 30.3%, platelet count (Plt) of 38 thousand/mm3, creatinine (Cr) of 1.0 mg/dL, total carbon dioxide (TCO2) of 34 mmol/L, glucose of 113 mg/dL, and several other abnormal lab results indicating potential organ dysfunction. 

The patient has been diagnosed with hypernatremia (high sodium), cirrhosis of the liver, alteration in nutrition, hypotension (low sodium, hyposmolality), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), renal failure, acute (acute renal failure), sepsis, severe (with organ dysfunction), and is currently being treated accordingly.

   picture is concerning for an influenza type picture, although she has a
   negative DFA, or a bacterial PNA, or both.  She was found to have two
   speciations of yeast growing in her BAL cultures, as well as in
   multiple sputum cultures.
   .
   # Severe sepsis: Hypoxia and hypotension concerning for infectious
   process with criteria sufficient for SIRS/sepsis given leukocytosis and
   tachypnea.  Potential infectious sources include bacterial pneumonia or
   influenza as above. Alternative infectious sources include SBP or
   urosepsis. Currently off pressors.  Influenza DFA negative.  Sputum and
   BAL positive for two species of yeast.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn/Cipro (day 3) for HAP.
   - CXR today to assess difficulty weaning, as well as fevers
   - Send beta glucan and C. diff to work up continued fevers and failure
   to wean
   - f/u RUQ US final read
   - Deferring diagnostic paracentesis for now, as insufficient amount of
   ascites to safely perform procedure
   - f/u pan-culture including blood, urine, sputum, influenza sputum.
   - Continue Hydrocortisone for poor cortisol stimulation test
 weaned
   from 50 q6h to 25 q6h [**1-4**], wean to 25mg q12h [**1-5**].
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Given CXR demonstrating bilateraly
   patchy infiltrates as well as her history of cough, fever, and sore
   throat for 2-3 weeks, symptoms are concerning either for influenza or a
   post-influenza bacterial pneumonia.  She currently meets criteria for
   ARDS with a P:F <100, bilateral infiltrates, and no CHF. Other
   potential etiologies include IIPs including AEP and AIP, although less

   volume-cycled AC at ARDSnet settings. Attempted extubation.  Patient
   became agitated during SBP with sinus tachycardia to 130
s and
   hypertension to 180
s systolic.  Placed back on CMV, given Zyprexa and
   propofol.  Attempt another attempt to rapidly wean later today to
   minimize time off sedation.  Difficulty weaning from vent believed to
   be [**3-5**] encephalopathy vs. altered mental status [**3-5**] sedation.
   - Transition to PSV today and repeat ABG
   - CXR, beta glucan to w/u possible causes of difficulty weaning from
   vent
   - Per liver, consider bronch to r/o VAP if pt does not improve or

   - Per liver, consider fungal coverage if pt does not improve

   - If she doesn
t improve, consider doing esophageal balloon to evaluate

The patient has been diagnosed with hypernatremia (high sodium levels), hypotension (low sodium levels), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver, alteration in nutrition, and septic shock.
